trans-unit.source: Deploy Multiple Instances of Resources | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy Multiple Instances of Resources | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use copy operation and arrays in an Azure Resource Manager template to iterate multiple times when deploying resources.
trans-unit.target: Use copy operation and arrays in an Azure Resource Manager template to iterate multiple times when deploying resources.

trans-unit.source: Create multiple instances of resources in Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Create multiple instances of resources in Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to iterate in your Azure Resource Manager template to create multiple instances of a resource.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to iterate in your Azure Resource Manager template to create multiple instances of a resource.

trans-unit.source: copy, copyIndex, and length
trans-unit.target: copy, copyIndex, and length

trans-unit.source: Within the resource to create multiple times, you can define a **copy** object that specifies the number of times to iterate.
trans-unit.target: Within the resource to create multiple times, you can define a **copy** object that specifies the number of times to iterate.

trans-unit.source: The copy takes the following format:
trans-unit.target: The copy takes the following format:

trans-unit.source: You can access the current iteration value with the **copyIndex()** function, such as shown below within the concat function.
trans-unit.target: You can access the current iteration value with the **copyIndex()** function, such as shown below within the concat function.

trans-unit.source: When creating multiple resources from an array of values, you can use the **length** function to specify the count.
trans-unit.target: When creating multiple resources from an array of values, you can use the **length** function to specify the count.

trans-unit.source: You provide the array as the parameter to the length function.
trans-unit.target: You provide the array as the parameter to the length function.

trans-unit.source: Use index value in name
trans-unit.target: Use index value in name

trans-unit.source: You can use the copy operation create multiple instances of a resource that are uniquely named based on the incrementing index.
trans-unit.target: You can use the copy operation create multiple instances of a resource that are uniquely named based on the incrementing index.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might want to add a unique number to the end of each
trans-unit.target: For example, you might want to add a unique number to the end of each

trans-unit.source: resource name that is deployed.
trans-unit.target: resource name that is deployed.

trans-unit.source: To deploy three web sites named:
trans-unit.target: To deploy three web sites named:

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-0
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-0

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-1
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-1

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-2.
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-2.

trans-unit.source: Use the following template:
trans-unit.target: Use the following template:

trans-unit.source: Offset index value
trans-unit.target: Offset index value

trans-unit.source: You'll notice in the previous example that the index value goes from zero to 2.
trans-unit.target: You'll notice in the previous example that the index value goes from zero to 2.

trans-unit.source: To offset the index value, you can pass a value in the **copyIndex()** function, such as **copyIndex(1)**.
trans-unit.target: To offset the index value, you can pass a value in the **copyIndex()** function, such as **copyIndex(1)**.

trans-unit.source: The number of iterations to perform is still specified in the copy element, but the value of copyIndex is offset by the specified value.
trans-unit.target: The number of iterations to perform is still specified in the copy element, but the value of copyIndex is offset by the specified value.

trans-unit.source: So, using the same template as the previous example, but specifying **copyIndex(1)** would deploy three web sites named:
trans-unit.target: So, using the same template as the previous example, but specifying **copyIndex(1)** would deploy three web sites named:

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-1
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-1

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-2
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-2

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-3
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-3

trans-unit.source: Use with array
trans-unit.target: Use with array

trans-unit.source: The copy operation is particularly helpful when working with arrays because you can iterate through each element in the array.
trans-unit.target: The copy operation is particularly helpful when working with arrays because you can iterate through each element in the array.

trans-unit.source: To deploy three web sites named:
trans-unit.target: To deploy three web sites named:

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-Contoso
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-Contoso

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-Fabrikam
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-Fabrikam

trans-unit.source: examplecopy-Coho
trans-unit.target: examplecopy-Coho

trans-unit.source: Use the following template:
trans-unit.target: Use the following template:

trans-unit.source: Of course, you set the copy count to a value other than the length of the array.
trans-unit.target: Of course, you set the copy count to a value other than the length of the array.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could create an array with many values, and then pass in a parameter value that specifies how many of the array elements to deploy.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could create an array with many values, and then pass in a parameter value that specifies how many of the array elements to deploy.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you set the copy count as shown in the first example.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you set the copy count as shown in the first example.
